Overall, this remains my number 1 favorite cafe in the Hayes Valley!
author: Susan C.

description:
This is the first cafe I've been to where I don't hate myself for forgetting to bring my earphones!

I'm a grab-bag type of music listener, and they play a whole range of good things from oldies to light rock to light alternative. Oooh! Ohh! I think..Chicago is on right now! SCORE!

I've managed to spend 6 hours here with 2 cups of London Fog + 1 slice of cranberry/orange bread for a mere $4.50! (just 50 cents for the 2nd cup of London Fog bc I didn't get a new tea bag, just the steamed milk). 

Though, with only 7 small tables and about 14 chairs, I wouldn't recommend coming in large groups here. Definitely made for a solo trip (or with a buddy). 

My favorite thing about this place is that they've managed to transform such a small spot to a very chic, modern, and comfy cafe that is decorated very nicely. Very clean. And the bathroom is very small, but clean and tiled nicely, too!

The only thing I think that can be improved is the size of the chairs: they're so small my butt hurts! (Or maybe that's because I've been sitting here for 6 hours..). But yea, I could go for bigger chairs.

As for parking, there is indeed a nearby parking lot...but it's not a "private lot" as Yelp mislead me =(. It's a nearby public lot that cost $10!

Luckily, there is residential parking (with unlimited hours..atleast...I hope so. I havent' checked my car in the last 6 hours...) just a few blocks away. 

And yes, FREE WI-FI with LOTS OF OUTLETS!
author: Gail N.

description:
I come here for my morning coffee and bagel fix before work pretty frequently now. 

It's pretty solid. The coffee is good, but not amazing and it saves me from being a fatty and eating pastry at La Boulange across the street. Instead, I eat bagels coated in cream cheese... I think it's a good compromise.
author: Abbey S.

description:
Was looking for a place to chill with my laptop and get a snack.  Table space is pretty limited here, so I ended up sitting outside, which was kinda nice, though it eventually got chilly (fortunately by then there was space inside).

I had a toasted croissant with ham and cheese.  The cheese was not quite melted, and it really felt "warmed," not "toasted."  It was still good, though.  Also had my favorite standby: decaf soy mocha.  The coffee was tasty, but served a little cooler than I'd like (and I'm the kind of person who can't handle really hot liquids).

There is supposedly free wifi, but my laptop wasn't in the mood to connect.  Fortunately my phone can act as a hotspot, or I woulda left right there to find another cafe.
author: Brian T.

description: Got a breakfast sandwich here once and I mean, maybe it's cheap/convenient/something that clearly has gotten this place 4 stars, but they microwave the eggs/ sandwich. It was... not tasty.
author: Richa A.

description:
This is the closest coffee shop to my house, so maybe I'm biased.  I've gotten to know all of the staff very well.  They're all very cool and friendly people.  Even the owner, George stops by every once in a while and he's also very nice.  The coffee is very good for the price.  The food is also a good deal, breakfast sandwiches are reasonably priced and filling, the lox bagels are gigantic towers of salmon with a bagel somewhere underneath.  You get a lot for your money.

The walls have art for sale and it changes pretty often.  The place has a very cool vibe and I will always come here even though I could just as easily go to ritual or blue bottle.  I'm glad this cafe is part of my neighborhood.
author: John G.

description:
A great space to grab a cup of coffee or tea.  Free wifi, nice gas fireplace mounted in the wall, and excellent customer service.  The gal working the counter is friendly to all who come in from all walks of life.  Genuine care really goes a long way.  

One star was taken away just because the seats weren't too comfy, but I suppose that's to keep wifi hogs like me from posting up for too long!
author: Michelle M.

description:
Lovely location but very, VERY unfortunate service. I didn't mind the Nag Champa being burned or the pothead cartoon on the tip jar, but the long-haired baristo was a total space-cadet. It seems that there is only one sandwich on the menu, which is very poorly written and makes no sense to read. I ordered said sandwich and a chai latte. It was 2:00 (after the lunch rush) and I was the only one ordering, with no orders being made ahead of mine. 
They guy proceeded to make my latte, set it aside on the counter (didn't hand it over to me or even tell me it was ready so I could grab it myself) and then spent a full twenty minutes making a cold vegetable and cheese sandwich. I could have made it better and faster myself. By the time he had finished meditating over my sandwich (or whatever he was doing that took him 20 minutes), the latte was room temperature and the bread, which he had toasted, had turned to cold toast. 
The best part is that he apologized for the wait, as if he knew how ridiculous it was that it took him so long.
MORAL OF THE STORY: Do not buy a sandwich from someone who is obviously very, very stoned.
author: Jen M.

description: Not a regular coffee drinker but can appreciate a well-made latte every so often. Here was excellent! Sunday afternoon and needed a fix and so I mentioned was planning to have drinks later so couldn't decide either small or large. Surprisingly, he suggested small (thought most would suggest medium forward sales) and an extra shot. Big props!
author: Coy T.

description:
Pretty cute place.  Decent coffee (not great, but decent).  The barista is an interesting guy, a little loud, but not mean. 

Out of the way for me, so I won't be back, but it was a fun place to do some European trip planning with my guy.
author: Adam T.

description: 5 stars because of Kim, the morning barista. She has to be the friendliest, nicest person ever! Always smiling, even at 8am. Otherwise, a nice place to get some work done.
author: Briana N.

description: I wish this place was better with service, food and internet access. The atmosphere is cozy and it's in a great location in the heart of Hayes Valley. I sometimes come in for coffee, which is okay. But every time I've ordered food, it's been mediocre at best. They claim free wifi, but it's very spotty and reliable maybe half the time. I used to overlook these drawbacks, but today I saw the guy behind the counter treat a customer very poorly and that was enough to turn me off for good. A girl waiting for a friend to arrive tried to use the washroom and the guy stopped her, saying she needed to pay for something before using it. When she kindly explained that she was waiting for a friend and would buy something in a few minutes, he rudely told her that if she didn't like it she could leave. Manners aside, this shows a basic lack of common sense. A few minutes later the girl's friend arrived and of course they left for one of the many other cafes around the corner. With a simple courtesy that costs nothing Cafe La Vie could have had three happy customers singing their praises. Instead, they've lost at least three customers permanently, likely more given the ripple effects, and brought on this review.
author: Stephen B.

description:
Coffee: Ok - i had the carmel mocha and it was a little too sweet and no better then the local starbucks coffee (yes, starbucks in the  constant that i use).

Food: OK- i had the veggie bagel with avocado. It had no flavor and fell apart after the first bite! I actually felt sick after eating it, I think it was the cream cheese.

Positive: Free Wifi :)

I would come back for the free wifi but try something different.
author: Harvinder K.

description: good study spot. outlets, quiet, nice workers, good bagels, the coffee is FUCKING TERRIBLE. i drink decaf maybe its their decaf blend but seriously that is absolutely not an excuse.
author: Alex P.

description:
Free wifi .. Quick service and friendly too. 
Please tip well. 
good friendly neighborhood.
author: B H.

description:
I come in regularly to download large files using their Wifi, as it's free, unsecured, and terribly fast. However, I'm not too impressed with the atmosphere or the food, and even the service. This is the kind of place with usuals who are more like furniture, but not the kind of place I'd like to hang out at, or take my friends.

Ordered an Americano and was asked how much water I'd like for the first time. Confused, I asked for three-quarters full, to which he spilled a bit out of the brimming cup and burned himself. Seating is weirdly tight for a place that is not particularly busy and results in passive aggressive leaning and proximity to plug in laptop chargers.
author: Peter H.

description: I love reading negative reviews. You people are HILARIOUS, and have clearly never worked in the service industry. This place is great! It's one of the best bargains in Hayes Valley, for this poor gay boy at least. The food is always good, the coffee does what its supposed to do, and the staff is wonderful.
author: Justin G.

description:
Cozy and quiet. Great place to work with free wi-fi and friendly service! I like the music they play too - boots my productivity level.

This place is on my top 5 favorite places to work from my laptop in the city.
author: Ashley K.

description:
Darling.  Simple.  Cozy.  NO ATTITUDE! 

I'll deduct a smidgen for the "weird chairs" factor.  Indeed the indoor chairs are a bit different.  If you are tall - not helpful.  Even the small-boned, small-bottomed men I saw fiddling intently with their lappies admitted "yup, the chairs are uncomfortable."

So I opted for a bar stool and counter height table.  Pretty good.  Great little  view onto leafy Octavia.  A nice perch for an hour or two.

Love the house music.  With one exception.  During a quieter period of the afternoon, the totally nice barristo got busy with cleanup duty (alert the media - they CLEAN the place!) and let the jazzed-up version of Ravel's "can't remember what you call it thing that goes on for f*c#ing" ever basically.. go on forever.  And it wasn't Bolero.  It was the other one.  Ugh.

High quality mocha.  No idea what it was - good quality powdered cocoa in the coffee?  Nice.

BATHROOM ALERT.  BATHROOM ALERT.  It's nice!  Tiled, pretty, clean and well lighted.  

Holy crap - a civilized hole in the wall wifi spot with attitude-free friendly barristi.  

Looking forward to my next visit, guys.
author: Juliana C.

description: Within its genre, high marks for a chill locals' coffee spot, cheap in comparison to others, and always the friendliest.  If you are in Hayes Valley, it's a way to avoid a line and have a nice conversation with a friend, dither on the Internet, or chill after yoga (my personal favorite)
author: Patrick B.

description:
I'm taking KO out for dinner tonight for recommending this place. I got here precisely three minutes ago to get some work done on this gorgeous Sunday, and I'm already writing this review. Cafe La Vie is my new found love. I mean seriously, I thought I fell in love when I found Marc Jacobs, Gucci or Joseph Cozza, but this little coffee shop (two blocks from home) even makes Tom Ford's new sunglasses look shabby. Giant open windows, excellent menu for coffee and nibbles, free wifi, and a hunk behind the counter makes you feel like turning the powerbook's new camera function on (I can send it to all of ya). And guess why I feel like home here? Coz I see like 20 mac users all around me. None of that Windows PC bullshit.

Now I have to find a cool matching bag for my mac from Ro or Marc Jacobs. Kenneth Cole or Jack Spade is not gonna cut it for this hip spot. Cafe La Vie deserves better. That's the only dilemma I have encountered so far. Jade has a sister coffee shop now!
author: Sav B.

description:
4 stars for the space.  It's small, but it's cozy, modern and lovely.  The outdoor seating is nice as well.

Minus one star for the regular drip coffee which was just "eh".  My friend dug her latte though.

Minus one star for one of the girls working the random Saturday I afternoon I found myself there.  The lid to the half n' half fell into my coffee and when I brought my cup, complete with empty half n' half container and lid inside my drink, she took the lid out of my drink and poured the SAME COFFEE INTO A DIFFERENT CUP.  

It's drip coffee.  I did not ask for anything that  would take an effort to make .  You will not lose money for a measly 16 oz. cup of drip coffee.  Why she did not just dump the lid-infested coffee and pour me another is beyond me.

Minus another star for giving me that fake "Uh, sorry 'bout that" kinda smile. 

Plus one star for the new guy behind the counter when we inevitably came back to the Cafe after sitting in the Park for a couple hours.  I got one of their Japanese bottled iced teas and it was awesome as was the new friendly guy behind the counter.  

I'll probably stick to Momi Toby's or Blue Bottle while I'm in Hayes Valley.
author: Jen I.

description:
Having just moved to Hayes Valley Ive been looking for a good cafe to sit down for a bit of study time. 

While Blue Bottle kicks a** it is seriously lacking in the chair-like mechanisms department suited to hold one comfortably for extended periods of time while delving into obscure topics like Postmodernism and the New World or whatever other quirky delight my Professors decide to bestow upon my fortunate soul. 

So I took a walk around the neighborhood and find myself sitting in Cafe La Vie. 

Coffee- check. Taste-meh. Chairs-check. Comfortable? Attuned to the frequency of a man suffering through the disregard for the structure of the English language that Postmodernist authors flaunt? LACKING. Seriously though these chairs are wack and the tables are small. 

Also Cafe La Vie seems to be attempting an imitation of a borderland swamp because the flies be a' stormin my friends and the sandwich crumbs and dressings abound on the floor......lets hope I find a better spot the next time around.....
author: Thomas P.

description:
I know what you're thinking. 

You're thinking - this is exactly what San Francisco needs - another coffee shop, with a chalkboard menu. And some croissants. Maybe odwalla. Maybe some sandwiches and bagels. Yes. This is what you've been waiting for. There aren't approximately 1,000 other places just like this all over the city. 

But, wait! Here's one thing that Cafe La Vie that is going to blow your mind. Are you ready? The coffee here ... is GOOD. Yes, it tastes good. It's not burnt. It's not watery. It's not BROWN (coffee should be black. hello!). You can drink this coffee and actually enjoy how it tastes ,as opposed to tolerating the shitty swill most places serve and waiting for the caffeine to hit your veins. What a revelation. 

Also, I saw the best post one night stand meeting here between two guys. One guy came to pick something up he left at the other dude's house and the painful look in his face told me all I needed to know. I'm sure you're double parked and have to leave right away. So very sure.
author: Maria D.

description:
Late July 07: 
Beah sits at Cafe La Vie trying desperately to get the free wifi to work. The signal is crystal clear but her computer just won't connect. People around her are starting to complain about the same problem. The  barista finally locates the wifi hub and resets it. Beah waits. Beah tries again. No luck. Others begin to agitatedly ask the barista "where else in the godforsaken neighborhood they might find a signal that actually WORKS." Beah roles her eyes because she doesn't like obnoxious, self-righteous customers but, deep down, is pretty disappointed about the wifi thing because she REALLY needs to check facebook. Just kidding. But she REALLY needs to check yelp.

Late September 07: 
Beah returns to Cafe La Vie, laptop in hands, ready to pound out hours of productive work. She assume the wifi snag has been corrected over the intervening two months. She is wrong.

Luckily, there are other signals within range that one can steal from. Beah works feverishly, though somwhat miffed that Cafe La Vie is still false advertising a free wifi signal.

OK. I'm pretty much over it. I'll probably go back this afternoon and get some more of that refreshing mint iced tea and maybe a Chai when the sun goes down. The space itself is beautiful and sunny, which is pretty invaluable as far as my seasonally depressed ass is concerned.

And a note on the chairs: while I am typically suspicious of the comfort level of chairs that are designed to appear un-chair-like (as Cafe La Vie's are), these guys are the exception. They are phenomenally comfortable to me, which is a major selling point for those preparing to sit at their laptop for hours one end. Mitigating this fact is the somewhat awkward table height. I need another couple of inches from you guys. Do I sound like a real asshole? I do, right?
author: Beah B.

description:
La Vie - a painting by Picasso, done in his "blue period" (1901-1904), which essentially means the period of his life where he was super tortured and upset because one of his best friends, Carlos Casagemas, committed suicide. Depressing shit, but the result was some pretty amazing art, if a little blue, literally. If you are ever in Cleveland go check out La Vie at the Museum of Art. 

Am I giving the place 5 stars just because I like Picasso? No, that wouldn't make any sense, would it? I am just pointing out that La Vie is pretty great as a painting AND as a cafe in Hayes Valley, and that I like art, and that this particular La Vie is all about showcasing local artists, and is artistic in its very design. Plus I am sharing a bit of art history with you in the process, and there is nothing wrong with a little education, is there? Well? 

Anyhow, this place has free wifi, doors that roll up on a nice day to let in the fresh air, a counter on the ceiling, red and orange hues (sort of like Picasso's "rose period" (1905-1907) combined with his "cubist period" (1909-1919), cozy seating and, drum roll please.........

Good coffee! Yes, an independent cafe with good coffee! You heard it here. You also heard a bit about Picasso. With a name like La Vie I couldn't resist!
author: Drue C.

description: Quick and easy. Good sandwiches and coffee. Friendly staff. Kool place. Veggie sandwiches are the best I've had.  Everything is good on the menu. Dog friendly place. Not hectic. No long lines. Good prices.
author: v c.

description:
DRINKS:
1.) White Mocha = yay I asked for it foamy um I dunno it's good i guess  not really a coffee connoisseur  :P


SERVICE:
eh good enough


ATMOSPHERE:
It's cute, I think better for warm days because they have outdoor seating and they open up one of the window walls to the outdoor. But yeah even though it's small, it's nicely designed, wood floors, hanging lamps, track lighting, this pretty neat framed fireplace in the wall haha..
author: Angela L.

description:
Free wifi and good coffee in an intimate upscale retro-modern George Jetsons atmosphere.  The owner, George, is a plumbing contractor so he is handy and creative.  He has a good eye for design too.  All of that explains why Oxenrose's old reception desk has been repurposed as a canopy over the order counter.

Only for the small to mid sized of tush.  The upside down conical section chairs are sturdy and gorgeous but not welcoming to bountious butts.

The espresso machine is a beauty.  I don't know if it's a special model but it's art art deco wonder.
author: Gil S.

description:
Before I say anything, the place has a garage door wall which opens up to the sidewalk. This, by default, was it's saving grace and prompted the last star to be added to the ranking. It was pretty cool to sit inside and have it feel like you were outside on a great SF day. 

That said, I'm surprised at the complete lack of cafe's in Hayes Valley. It gets some of the City's best weather and from what I can tell, there are about 3 that can truly count as your typical study/work/chat coffee shop. Cafe La Vie was my top choice of the 3 for the simple fact that it has: free wifi, power outlets and "food". The first two are given pluses but the food options were terrible. 

Ok, so this is probably where local fans of the place start yelling at me BUT food is important. I don't drink coffee and really, if you're going to tap into a places power supply and chillax there for a couple hours laptopping, spending money on a meal is a must. This place is small and has no kitchen so I guess what could I really expect for a meal. But still, it was disappointing to say the least. I ended up with the daily special: turkey sausage gumbo which ended up being minestrone with small sausage pieces in it. Oh well.

Service is great. The music selection is random but toned down enough that it doesn't really get to you. Seating and table space are a bit limited inside so that might restrict your laptopping requirements. In the end, I was able to get a good amount of work done albeit I was starving by the time I left. In the end, this place is great if you're looking to do anything but eat.
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description:
Friendly service, amazing almond croissants, and the perfect cup of coffee...or latte...or cafe au lait....or espresso....
there is also a very sexy customer named Tito who often goes in to order double espressos with water. I'd try to catch him in the morning if you can...what a treat ;)
author: Raquel C.

description:
I wish the ironic moustache trend would end sooner rather than later. Most men just can't pull it off, and trust me, the few who can are not scrawny little white hipster boys. Not to mention any irony was lost as soon as it became a trend.

Okay, enough on the clientele. The iced tea and iced coffee were pretty good. The internet signal was strong, but the tables were tiny with several chairs all squished together. The chairs were also more decorative than comfortable. Not a good study spot unless you already live in the area, and definitely not good for a large group, but the coffee makes it worth going for a while at least.
author: Sara G.

description:
Thank the caffeine Gods there is another coffee option in Hayes Valley.  Sometimes I don't want to wait in line for Blue Bottle especially when I want a capuccino or latte because for some reason, they seem to make mine lukewarm.  If I'm not going for a crack drip at Blue Bottle, I head to Cafe La Vie for a nice hot excellent capuccino.

The interior is cozy and cool in design, you know like Ritual but a fraction of the size.  Cafe La Vie is also on the cutest tree lined block of Octavia you know by the African store?  It reminds me of Europe.   I love that area, and I can tell it loves me too.  

There you go.
author: James M.

description: Pretty cool spot. True story bro. Seems like a chill place with a mini sit down area of comfy chairs and a bench. Very kind barristas and the pastry combo for the win (pastry plus coffee 3 bucks).
author: Greg G.

description:
Lately I have been lost for words. Can not seem to say what I mean. Everything that flows out of thy lips is misconstrued.

Until...

I took my sip of the cafe mocha...

"Woah!"

I really did mean to express each letter and punctuation in that 5 character space.
author: Cathy H.

description:
The pluses: lively neighborhood, friendly quick service, lots of vegan cookies from Alternative Baking Company
The minuses: only ok soy latte flavor, weak lighting, cramped interior, not very comfortable seating whether soft or hard, asked for latte "for here" and received it in a paper cup.
author: Bob G.

description:
There's nothing like getting to know about new places early. REALLY early. In this case, about 2 months early.

I was in Hayes Valley enjoying the pre-xmas street festivities, when I came across the owners of Cafe La Vie sitting next to the open main window of their soon-to-be cafe. I was, admittedly, in the mood for a coffee, but this place wasn't going to open until Jan or Feb at least. 

Still, there was something about it that charmed me.. maybe the flat fireplace set against the wall like a picture, maybe the burning man crowd playing with fire just down the road from me, or maybe just the buzz from drinking on an empty stomach. I decided that this was to be my cafe, and I it's champion... So, keep an eye on this place, coming soon!
author: Kevin R.

description:
One of the most important features of a good apartment is access to coffee. And I'm not talking mini-mart coffee or Starbucks but rather, cute, unique coffee shops, like this one. In an effort to get to know my new neighborhood (and again, in an effort to effectively telecommute) I started wandering through Hayes Valley and came across this gem. While small inside, it has great outdoor seating, and the front wall of windows open up so that even inside eaters can feel like they are outside (or, as the case maybe, inside office space can be outside office space too!). I didn't have coffe, but I did have a cookie and it was very good - breakfast of champions. Likewise, the guy at the counter had a great music selection going - very hipster but not distracting. 

Note: This place DOES have internet access - it's not secured and didn't show up at the top of my available wireless list. You might have to scroll down a bit, but it's there with a good signal.
author: Jenna G.

description:
I think I found my new favorite café.

Come here if you happen to find yourself wandering around Hayes Valley.  It's a great little spot for a coffee or snack.
author: Scott R.

description:
This is a great little coffee shop on Octavia. It's nestled behind a few trees so it may not jump out at you, but there are always people typing away with the free WiFi on their comfy couches. 

(I accidentally confused this place and put a scathing review up for La Boulange - I have only had great service at Cafe La Vie and haven't seen a hair in my food yet. :)
author: Trev C.

description:
Tiny little cafe.  Great cookies for half-off a la 50c in the afternoon..  Also have various bagels and a sandwich of the day...  Tuna, last Friday.

Saw some people sitting at the small high tables with laptops.  If they have wireless, Hayes Valley finally has more than just Cafe Grillades, woop!
author: Melanie C.

description:
Came here on a rainy afternoon with a friend and it was empty, which was nice because we got to snatch a table by the windows.

They won me over by playing some Modest Mouse and Smashing Pumpkins on the stereo, though they went through periods of playing music and periods of silence.  Their coffee was great - rich but not overpowering.  There are some really neat art on the walls also and the feel was minimalistic but cozy.  

However, they get a -1 star because I couldn't figure out who's comfort they had in mind when they purchased those chairs.  Gnomes, maybe.  Not humans.
author: Andrew P.

description: Cute place to grab coffee and majorly delicious bagel with veggies!  Free wifi but not the best set up for studying or laptoping...better for reading or chatting.  There was only one lady working but she was super friendly and quite speedy!
author: Melinda H.

description:
I was walking down Hayes thinking I'd head over to Blue Bottle for a latte, when I noticed a sign for Cafe La Vie. Sure, why not? I didn't want to elbow my way through the coffee hipsters on Linden St anyway. (despite how enamored I am by the Blue Bottle barrista's latte foam artwork of leaves and hearts)

The coffee here is quite good. I was pleased to notice their perfect score (100 points) on their latest health inspection. I have to agree with Jimmy C. that their rubbery, puffy stools aren't the most comfortable things. ...but the cozy atmosphere, artwork, fresh flowers, good lighting, and open windows make it otherwise inviting. I can't wait to come back for an iced coffee and a good book this summer.
author: Richie K.

description:
Cheaper then Peet's and closer...uh oh. My heart may have been stolen...

Ok not permanently but this place is oober close and really yummy. I love the mini fireplace in the wall inside, and the drinks? Unique...different....no just chai lattes for days

Cookies you quit lookin at me like that!!

Everyone in here has been super nice, its never been overly crowded, and I must say their espresso is quite good. Has a homey feel to it cause you cashier is also your coffe maker is also everything....makes a gal; feel like number 1 ya know?

I take one star away cause the first few times I came here the cups were disfunctional and leaked coffee on me. 
Note: hasn't happened since tho....this batch of cups must be better.
author: Stacy L.

description:
1. Free Wi-Fi and workers who don't care how long you sit there with an empty coffee cup.

2. Great location.

3. Cool gas fireplace in the back.

4. Usually good music.

5. Sidewalk Seating
author: Julia G.

description:
I will give 2 stars just because the latte I ordered was good.

But other than that, the workers here are rude.
NOT friendly AT ALL!
I wanted to go to Apollo today, but unfortunately the place was
full.  So I decided to come to Cafe LA Vie since I always passed by 
here and wondered if it was good.

Well, now I know.  CAFE LA VIE is TERRIBLE.

I believe that FIRST IMPRESSION is very very important.
The girl here who supposedly speaks French had no smile,
gave me the shortest spoon ever for my parfait ( had to
ask for the spoon by the way; did she expect me to eat with
my hand?)-- and when I saw a table that no one was using, 
but had little art materials like pencils and sketchbook,
I asked if I could sit there.  Apparently the stuff belonged to 
one of the workers.  Even though they let me use the table,
GOSH did she seem so bothered by my request...WTF?!
There's only so many tables here and I (as a customer) wanted
to SIT!  

Besides, I said I was having coffee here. Why does EVERYONE gets
a MUG, and I get a PAPER-CUP?

Seriously, Seriously, Seriously, WTF.
I felt very unwelcome here, and obviously, will NEVER come
here again.

oh, by the way, the bathroom here is also dirty and gross.

I don't understand why the rating is so high here, but hey, I just
remembered some of my friends saying this place is below O.K.
So obviously you shouldn't always believe the ratings on yelp.
author: Shine W.

description: I drag my ass to work day after day,  but I find I am downright chipper when I stop to get my coffee at Cafe La Vie!  The staff are so cool and laid back, and the lox,  bagels, and coffee are awesome. I took my dogs with me on a Saturday and was bummed that my favorite barista ( jessica?) doesn't usually work on weekends. Oh well, but my canine buddies got treats at the cafe and I got a yummy Espresso.  Enjoy your over-priced pretencious Blue Bottle, more La Vie for me!
author: Fawn L.

description: My neighborhood place for coffee.  Relaxed without the long line and wait at other nearby cafes.  I've never stopped by and had to wait for a place to sit.  Plus free wifi and 11th coffee is free!
author: Ron N.

description: Just off the beaten path in in Hayes Valley, this little cafe is a quiet, relaxing spot perfect for a casual conversation. Cafe La Vie has free internet, but hardly any real tables to set up a workstation if you're really trying to get sh*t done. The staff is great, patrons are friendly - you immediately get a sense that this spot is very integrated into the neighborhood. I would give Cafe La Vie a much higher rating if I wasn't such a cafe-workaholic.
author: Vince L.

description: I work in this neighborhood of numerous excellent cafes, but this is my favorite.  Great coffee (not like there's not a lot of competition there!), really good light food (not either), BUT the atmosphere (local art, chill scene), and most of all the staff!!!!
author: Buddy B.

description: Very friendly local business.  Great place to stop in for a delicious, well priced bagel or sandwich, and great coffee!
author: Mike W.

description:
Since this is the closest coffee shop to me, you will usually find me here for an hour or two after work, just relaxing. If that isn't enough to make you check this place out (or, more likely, stay away), it also has a really laid back feel, everyone is really nice, and they make great espresso drinks. I've never had the drip, so I have no idea how it is. 

update: they have wifi again! And it works, too!
author: Edward C.

description:
Nice easy walk, street are all flat around there.
Very good coffee & breakfast items
Great fast service.
Friendly towards Dogs even have Dog treats too.
Outside table and chairs to rest on walk out & small park near by
author: Kurt G.

description:
Definitely not everything I hope it would be. The space is limited, and the chairs are fun, but not comfy. The iced coffee was delish though, so I'd get stuff to go from here. 

The barista needs to focus on the cafe, rather than some friend who has nothing better to do on a beautiful day than hang out with his working friend. 

good, not great.
author: Jenny M.

description:
I have been sitting here and working the whole day because its so warm outside!

I love the huge window/wall.  They slide it open all the way on warm days and it feels like you are sitting on a veranda.  Wifi is free, they dont mind people hanging out here the whole day.  The little leather chairs are very comfortable, and even though the place is rather small, they manage to fit 10 chairs in here, very smart use of the space!  The ceilings are high which adds to the space dimension.

Coffee is good and strong, good selection of teas, pomegranate is my favourite!  The barristers are nice and cool too!

This is a great place to lounge at
author: Anya T.

description:
More of a 3 1/2. 

Service really depends on who's standing in the back of the counter. The good-looking vest wearing guy in the morning is somewhat curt.

I find that the best time to come is in the afternoon and at night when the barista/cashier is A LOT more chirpy. But I guess it doesn't really matter when you need your coffee/sugar fix. 

Hot chocolate is good, but then again its hot chocolate. 

Bagel and lox is decent. 

But their price for bagel and cream cheese is ridiculous! A bagel is only $1.00, yet a bagel and cream cheese costs $2.50. How can they justify doing that? Seriously! Does a single serving smear of regular cream cheese that is bought in bulk--I saw the huge tub--cost  $1.50? 

 I think not!
author: Dorothy N.

description:
The coffee here is not good at all.  You are so much better off making the 2 block walk over to Blue Bottle instead if you're there for coffee.

However, if reliable free wifi and delicious M&M cookies are more your thing, and you don't mind sipping a mediocre latte, then this place is fine for you.  Oh, as long as you don't mind the flies that hang around whenever they open up the windows.
author: Taryn S.

description:
This adorable new spot in Hayes Valley has terrific coffee at low prices.  The cafe is full of brushed metal and looks almost nightclubbish.  The barista that served me was very friendly and has a level of adorable above and beyond the call of duty.

Oh, I can't wait to come back here.
author: Apollo L.

description:
Dear Peets,

The chairs in this place are just not working...  10 minutes max and you want to get out.

Great place for sitting outside, fix the chairs...!

Love, 
Jimmy
author: Michael R.

description:
Such a cute and chic place hidden in the alley!

Great spiced apple cider when it's not holiday season, just when I craved for it. Good coffee too, best option when you don't want to stand in line for 30 minutes fr Blue Bottle.
author: Yuchi C.

description:
Great Location. Great Patio. Cool decor. Free Wifi. Enough power plugs. Decent coffee. No real food. Shite music that's played loud. I mean I love music. Everybody loves music. Yet everyone does not love the same kind of music. That's ok... unless it's loud. Then it's a polarizing. Love it or else. 
I'm in the else category on 90% of today's music selection. We've gone for the relatively benign ungodly-overplayed-so-I-never-want-to-hear-it-again Violent Fems to bad tinny terrible folk music and noise bands that make Sonic Youth sound like the Symphony.

I spent the better part of a day working here. The music selection and volume do vary a bit based on the dripper-jock. I've also been here when this wasn't an issue. So... meh.
author: Jim y.

description:
I like the low key chill atmosphere.  I appreciate the free wifi.  I tend to use that most when I an unemployed in between jobs.  I wondered if it was ok that I was using something other than a Mac though.

Good mint tea and hot chocolate.  I just wish they stayed open later.
author: Aaron T.

description:
If there's two people in line your better off walking out. The service is slow. And they'll stop helping you to give free coffee to their buddies who walk to the back of the counter. Oh express line? 

Dude, it's a job, you'll still be cool if you give a shit. 

The coffee isn't bad we've just given up on eccentric weird staff. I'll check back in a year and see if that barista is still in a coma.
author: Hector M.

description: The barista, the coffee, and the atmosphere are the reasons to hit this place up.  The staff person was very quick, attentive, and personable.  She acted as if how she treated her customers actually mattered :-) I do not recommend getting any kind of breakfast sandwich....it was kind of underwhelming BUT, no regrets going there.  The coffee was great and the location was convenient.  The art on the walls (photographs of beautiful half naked women) kept me entertained.
author: Marissa K.

description:
I keep coming back here and it's really just out of convenience. I get a tea or a coffee and use their free wifi, all the while, thinking how I really wish I went elsewhere. I find it annoying how each time I've ordered my drink (no matter who the tattooed hipster worker is)  the worker barely gives me eye contact and maintains his/her loud conversation with one of her/his pals outside the cafe door. It's real poor customer service. 

Two stars for playing good music and having a *bit* of charm.  When I say bit, I mean more like a smidgen. Nevetheless, I'll probably still come back here and sit in the weird chairs for 3 hours typing and sipping away. C'est La Vie, Cafe La Vie.
author: joolia f.

description: Great cafe, and especially great people working here. It's a perfect neighborhood place for a mocha plus some food. The full windows are wonderful for sunshine.
author: Joel H.

description: Free wifi. Great coffee. Nice ambience. Dog friendly. What's not to like?!
author: Deborah F.

description:
I'm glad that I am one of many that love this cafe! I lived right across the street for a year and I nearly cried when I moved (only a block away) because I would be missing the staff, service, the luxury of rolling out of bed stumbling across Octavia and enjoying a nice variety of goodies and beverages. It's funny how the other side of Laguna feels less like Hayes Valley. 

The owner is a doll and the staff are trendy, down to earth and sweeter than the pastries they sell. I've stayed there for hours and never felt uncomfortable or unwanted. I've jumped in and out and had great personal service. 

I hate the tour service next to them and how the people who work there come in, jump the line, help themselves and act like assholes. The tourists are another story! They bring in the business and since the Cafe is a bit hidden it's good to see other local business' support one another, but c' mon people wait your turn! It's my turn to order my medium soy latte! Though this can a nuisance it's worth putting up with because La Vie is so fantastic!
author: Jessie J.

description:
I've lived in Hayes Valley for about 3 years now, and was around when this place first opened.  First off, George the owner is one cool cat.  Hes always there to greet customers or is off partying at the African Outlet, another cool hangout.

The espresso and coffee here is great, way better then Momi Tobi's (though Momi's does have a more "hip" environment).

In addition, George let me host the release of my new Zine, SynergyZine, at the cafe, where we had over 60 people come through to hear live poetry and drink wine. Hows that for community, eh?
author: Michael G.

description: I love this place. Everything about it is so cute. I love the vibe I got every time I walked in here. This place was part of my daily routine walk. Coffee then the muni... The workers here are so awesome. I will def visit this cafe when I get back to the city.
author: Berenice D.

description: I occasionally stop by this coffee shop on my way to work. Good large drip coffee for less than $2. Friendly service. There's usually only one or two people working so sometimes there's a bit of wait for orders. They remember their regulars and have small talk with them which at times can add to a wait.
author: Vicky C.

description:
On the radio: Classical Music 

Behind the counter: awesome, attentive, friendly baristas

In my cup: A shot of espresso, steamed milk, and foam

Other I notice in the cafe: some long-haired dude playing mandolin and a few people on their laptops 

What I'm thinking: This is definitely my spot for my morning brew, afternoon study-session, and evening pick-me-up before a symphony concert.
author: Laura R.

description: Nice place to stop by for a latte while walking the dog.  They are pooch friendly which helps since my dog doesn't like to wait outside by himself and I'm embarrassed by his barking whenever I have to leave him.  They even have a little jar of treats which is a bonus.
author: Maria L.

description:
i know how to get free coffee here.  you just gonna take them to the back storage with you and tip them good.

just playin.

this is definitely a good neighborhood cafe, in the old hood!
author: Richie K.

description: I love this place!! A real cafe, very neighborhood.  Not over priced, great service, great food and coffee.
author: Erik E.

description: A nice, chill coffee shop. Nice atmosphere, comfortable chairs, and the coffee is pretty good. Free wifi too.
author: Dana L.

description:
Dear Peet's,

You know how difficult is for me to write letters like this, and I know it makes it uncomfortable for the both of us, so I'll try to get right to the point.  We've had some good times, I know, and frankly I've sort of been noticing this new cafe opening up in the 'hood.  I've peeked in her windows as she underwent construction and she looked quite charming, to say the least.  Well, Peet's, she uh, she kind of opened finally and I needed to -- how do I put this gently? -- go in to try her wares.  Well, she's really pretty.  And her drinks are well-made.  She has nice artwork from local artists adorning the walls, and the entire front of her facade is a garage door that lifts and allows the incense and drum beats from The African Outlet two doors down to waft in.  There's a fireplace in the wall!  Comfy leather chairs!  A laconic atmosphere that is equal parts artsy and homey.  Peet's, I really like her and I think I'm going to be seeing more of her.  No, no, no ... please don't look at me like that.  It's not that I'm leaving you.  No, that's not it at all.  We'll still hang from time to time.  I can never LEAVE you, leave you.  It's just, well, she has Wi-Fi.  You don't.  I have certain ... NEEDS that you just can't scratch.  I'll always love you Peet's, and don't forget it.  You'll always have a place in my heart.  It's just ... what?  What's her name?  It's Cafe La Vie.  Good, local flavor.  It's new.  And I think I'm going to fall in love with her.

Love always,
Thomas B.
author: Thomas B.

description: I just moved into the neighborhood and stumbled on Cafe La Vie on a sunny Sunday afternoon.  Great location, great staff, great coffee AND free wifi!  What more could you want in a coffee house?
author: Chris M.

description: Worlds most uncomfortable coffee shop. All of the seating choices they made were intended to keep your from spending more than 15 minutes there. Which makes the free wifi worthless, by the time you pull your laptop out and get connected your ass is telling you it's time to leave. The coffee is nothing to write home about. The service is great, super nice people. The location is nice and sitting outside is enjoyable because it gets the afternoon shade. Just don't plan on staying very long.
author: Michael H.

description: Great owner, chill, music-savvy baristas who know how to make a mean Americano when you most need one, sidewalk seating, fresh bagels and a roll-up front window make for the neighborhood place to kick back, read the paper and chill out in true Euro cafe society tradition.
author: Deborah C.

description: Great breakfast sandwich, great coffee, great ambience, and friendly staff. Casual neighborhood coffee shop as it should be.
author: Andrew O.

description: I love this off-the-main-drag of Hayes Valley cafe.  The coffee won't empty your pocket change, even the largest espresso based drinks are less than $3.  The atmosphere is chill - I just listened to a song from the Amelie soundtrack.  The furnishings are clean, with hardwood floors and leather arm chairs in red and grey.  A couple of fun high top tables and al fresco tables out front.  The window is a huge garage door that opens to the top of the high ceilings.  Very airy, and very free internet.  This is the perfect spot for a couple of hours of work.  Don't crowd it out though, it's my secret internet cafe.
author: Mandy S.

description:
Love the outside seating.
Love how they can open the windows  and the cafe expands into the sidewalk.  
Love the soy latte!!!! So delicious!
Love the people that work there. Super chill.
author: Jag B.

description: First impression: wow, this place is a lot smaller than I expected! The space is tiny, but there are quite a few seats and conveniently located power outlets to feed your electricity habit. The free wifi and relaxed atmosphere make this a good place to work on your laptop, although the uncomfy chairs and cramped spaces are a pain. During the day they raise the glass garage door, must be very nice on a warm day! Pretty cold in November though. The coffee was not excellent, but good. I'd go back if I was in the neighborhood and wanting a coffee or some internet time.
author: Will A.

description:
what yuppie art! but besides that, cafe la vie is a gem on a sunny warm day with the large window rolled up. enjoy a cool orangina and sit with the sun kissing your face and the gentle breeze rolling by. nice for reading heavy tomes or opt to be social and have a conversation. the image this cafe projects: clean, neat, trendy (aka mac users only), healthy?, cute. but i fear that espresso drink so i'll refrain for now.

...so the espresso is scary and not to my liking. It does not cool well,  more of a rancid taste at that point.
author: Faye P.

description: I am on the fence about this place.  I really like the neighborhood, and coffee is good, and it draws a cute crowd.  However, the chairs as one visitor noted are uncomfortable (maybe designed that way due to space constraints), and while the women behind the counter spin some good music, the guys, and one in particular, spins punk/acid rock which is just acerbic... right after lunch everyone goes from gently bobbing their heads or tapping foot to annoyance or to the door as the place empties out.  This has happened twice of my last two visits within this month.
author: K G.

description: Food and drink are prepared cheerfully, with a smile and pleasantries.  It is reasonably priced compared to some of the more boutique coffee and tea places in the neighborhood.  It even takes care of the homeless folks who live in the area.  There is nothing bad to say -- this is how a neighborhood coffee house should be.  Cheers to the owner and the wonderful people who work here.
author: David L.

description: Love it.... great little Hayes Valley addition! Really cozy... somewhat of a NY flavor to it. Cozy, hip and tasty. Try it.
author: Casandra E.

description: Reasonably good coffee with seating and free wifi in Hayes Valley has to get you some stars. This place, as my friend put it, has the distinctive feel of a hotel lobby. The seating is less than comfortable if you're in for the long haul (i.e. working on your laptop for hours). Then again, on a sunny day, they can open up the front of the cafe so that you can bask in the sunlight. That is definitely a plus.
author: Jen M.

description: I think I have found my new spot. My roommate and I went here for some ice tea this morning before I had to go to work.  I was delighted with the service, the atmosphere and most importantly: the delicious ice tea.  Next time I am def going to try some of the baked goods or a sandwich because everything seemed very appealing.  The guy behind the counter could not of been nicer, which is always a rare thing in the early morning.  There were tables outside where we sat and enjoyed the beautiful San Francisco sun.  All in all it was a great experience and seems to be an awesome addition to the Hayes Valley that I only wish I had discovered sooner.
author: ELIZABETH W.

description:
"YAY!" to free wifi and an extra one for having power outlet! pretty solid internet connection. it is nice to have a local spot in the neighborhood to work. there's usually a spot to work. 

during the summer, it's nice to sit outside with a book. most of the barista are nice and place good music. coffee is okay. the selection of tea is great - pomegranate oolong!
author: Jocelyn T.

description:
do you like to order coffee  -  sit and watch the world go by? then cafe la vie is your spot - it is simply one of the best cafes in san francisco - 

-great atmosphere
-good coffee and espresso drinks
-huge window that rolls up - :)
-free wifi
author: Christian S.

description: Great place! I love they have a giant "window" which is really a glass garage door. Free wifi which I love of course. The staff was very nice and I had the veggie sandwich which was very yummy. It's a great neighborhood cafe where people can just come in and hang out. I actually got work done ;)
author: Cindy L.

description: Cute. Tucked away. Free wifi. Clean. Reasonably priced drinks. Catchy, diverse playlist of music that distracted me from doing anything productive. Will definitely return.
author: serena l.

description: This place doesn't get as much traffic as everything on Hayes St. except when the tour bus from the company next door drops off.  They took my fav off the menu- chai with a shot of espresso but they'll still make it.  Figured out the trick- ask for regular, not soy milk and it's way less sweet.  Love the sidewalk seating and the free wifi.
author: laura a.

description: Great place, good coffee, comfortable seating and free wifi. Excellent.
author: Anil S.

description: So delicious.  And the guy behind the counter was cute and fun.  Nice place to sit and have a latte.
author: Shannon B.

description: It was not bad. My vanilla latte was surprisingly good (maybe because I always expect small cafes to skimp on the syrup) and the location can't be beat. As for the seating, if I were lucky enough to have a big butt, I'd feel discriminated against. As it was, my flat ass was just fine.
author: Grace C.

description: This is a great people-watching place! I ordered a bagel with lox, and it came with mounds of salmon -- a good deal at $5.25. The place is tiny but decorated nicely. Very comfy and a good place to sit and watch the world go by.
author: mandydale k.

description:
This is a cozy, neighborhood spot that really caters to what the locals want.  I've made some menu suggestions and - voila - they appear.   That's the beauty of locally-owned places -- the owner is there and open to suggestions.  He also has a knack for hiring some of the nicest baristas in town. Going in there is always a pleasant experience. 

Also the food is amazing. I love, love, love the sandwiches, the veggie bagel and the baked goods.  Overall - great service, good coffee, great food.
author: A S.

description: I don't drink Coffee, but this is right around the corner from my house, so when I'm "working" from home on a not so warm day, you can find me cozying up to the fireplace in the back. Free wifi, okay pastry's, good chai, and Italian sodas. Cool staff; music is sometimes good.  Did I mention free wifi?
author: Miss S.

description: cute little coffee spot. great spot to sit outside when it's sunny.
author: Mike P.

description: I give you five stars because I have been making and drinking coffee for years now, and yours was the only one that made me feel like I was on some sort of drug that speeds you up and makes you happy, I dont know what kind of drug that this would be since I dont do that shit, and have never done that shit because drugs are bad, anymore. It is super small and in a cool off the street location on Octavia. I have not had a bad experience here and my hag/wife lives across the street so if I end up in her bed instead of mine it is a good thing to wake up to since I feel like shit and dont remember how I got to her house kind of way, who is that sleeping next to me. Coffee is a drug.
author: Ryan O.

description: Once in a while, I go here for a bagel to go on my day off, I usually get a nice girl who's on top of it and down to earth. She seems to be friendly with all of the regulars and essentially just makes the small space cosy and pleasant. Today I went in and saw a man leaning against a back counter, berating the cashier. The cashier started to say hi to me and was interrupted by the jerk in the back, who was yelling at him to adjust a credit card tip while he greeted me. The woman who had tipped was waiting for two espresso drinks. The jerk asked how much the tip was. Weird, a little tacky. The cashier tried to talk to me and the jerk again yelled, "what about the lady's coffee, you're f***ing up, you're too f****ing slow." Damn. I don't mean to throw this around, but I am a cafe manager, and this was the worst "training" I've ever seen. It made the whole place feel tense and awkward. I ordered a sesame bagel with tomato. I got home, and there's no tomato, which I'm pretty sure that I paid for. Basically, I like this place, but the jerk has gotta go.
author: Isabel L.

description: Came here at 10 AM this morning to meet the photog for our son's up coming Bar MItzvah. All had various drinks including latte's, chai's, coffee with espresso and I had a bagel with lox for ONLY $5.25. Super fresh local high quality lox piled high. Would definitely come again.
author: Steve K.

description: i love this little coffee shop because it has comfy chairs, good coffee, a great little outdoor patio and free wifi. the music in the shop is horrible though! they used to play indie rock and a good mix of eclectic tunes but recently it's been a mix of bad oldies. come on peeps!
author: Kerri B.

description: This just opened in the last few months, and really - it's quite nice.  It has an interesting decor, artwork, a fireplace, service is quick and in my case - my chai latte was made by a very friendly and very cute barista, and wasn't watered down or anything..  Reasonable prices on things too...  I'll be back, and this isn't even in my neighborhood!
author: Omar A.

description:
the coffee is awesome. i always get the same thing and it never disappoints. you know how sometimes when you get a latte the coffee is so burnt, not even the sugar free cancer causing miracle that is splenda, helps you choke it down? well thats never happened here. 

the m&m cookies are doubly awesome. they're soft on the inside, crunchy on the outside goodness. it gives me the sugar rush i need to deal with the pretentious b&t/marina stroller brigade that comes parading into hayes valley every weekend. 

the staff is triply awesome. everyone is super nice and cool and nice. i know i already said nice, but that's how nice they are. 

anyways in summation, i know i used the word awesome a lot, but get over it and get some coffee and cookies here. 

the end.
author: kristy s.

description: This is a perfect spot to sit, drink and type away.  The free w-fi adds a huge plus and it's in a great neighborly atmosphere.
author: Fashionista M.

description: Fifth star confirmed. Great coffee, and the regular size was super generous.
author: Jason B.

description: OK, honestly you can get coffee and bagel at several places in the neighborhood, but I gotta say, this is my favorite cafe. It doesn't have that weird vibe like some of the other cafes do. This place is cosy, intimate, and friendly. It's perfect to be alone and still have some nice ambient sound without it preventing from doing your work.
author: Victoria A.

description: I love Cafe La Vie.  I go there every day (on my days off, anyway) for my coffee - just $0.75 if you bring your own mug!  I've gotten to know the staff a little and I like them a lot.  Cute deocr, free internet, free dog biscuits if you're into that, bagel options, pastries, etc.  Cheers!
author: Sarah H.

description: free wifi makes this a good place to do some work.  the menu is small, but the place is fairly quiet.
author: Helen T.

description: delicious pomegranate tea. the chai latte is really peppery, which is good if you like that sort of thing, but i like mine more sweet. i don't really like the interior, but on hot days when they open the "garage door" window, it's awesome. there's nothing like sitting barefoot in a sundress on that bench outside on a hot summer day drinking tea and reading david sedaris. 5 stars when it's 75 or warmer.
author: Jane P.

description: Great little place. My boyfriend and I stayed for a few hours working on art and reading. There were a lot of regulars that stopped in and the barista was friendly to everyone. I read lots of complaints about the chairs on yelp, but I thought they were super comfy. There is a fireplace and it was nice and cozy in there. Local art on the walls is always a plus. My caramel mocha was amazing and my boyfriend enjoyed his iced mocha. There was also good light, which is a must for me. I was super grossed out by the people who brought their dogs in with them to order and the fact that the barista didn't say anything about it. However, I don't know if she actually noticed because she was pretty busy and it unfortunately seems to be normal for San Francisco. Besides that, it was great and I'll just make sure not to sit next to door next time.
author: T C.

description: It's nice to have free wifi, but the music's always so loud that I can't really concentrate on whatever I'm doing. The owner also doesn't allow one to post flyers or leave postcards for events around the city, which I think is a bit curmudgeonly, especially since the cafe is supposed to be an artist-friendly space (it always has works by several local artists hanging on the walls). Coffee's ok, good clam chowder and bagel sandwiches, not too-comfy chairs....
author: larissa A.

description: Love the outside seating and the windows opening up on warm days.  I could sit here all afternoon sipping coffee with free wi-fi.
author: M S.

description: now i don't know if anyone else shares their wireless with their neighbors upstairs....ahem. but this place is a great place to get some work done, especially if your wifi poops out. it's got free wifi and has some good drinks and food (at very decent prices!). it also has a snazzy jet garage door so you can be a hermit inside while experiencing the great outdoors. definitely a good place to go to get a change of scenery!
author: stephanie q.

description:
i like coming here since i can generally get a seat.  the coffee is pretty good as well.  i also like the art they display.

but the most interesting thing here has to be the people.  EVERYTIME i am in here the oddest conversations and people seem to wonder in.  if i sit there for 20 min. i am will def. have a few stories to tell later.
author: n. h.

description: best coffee in the neighborhood - without the posers at Blue Bottle!
author: david f.

description: coffee was great, good music and cozy seats inside, nice outside sitting now that the trees are trimmed.
author: Glenn A.
